info.name: Scenario API
info.description:
# Introduction

The Scenario API is responsible for handling communication between the backend and the frontend of the Scenario Analysis Project. It's capable of receiving requests for creating, reading, and executing simulations, as well as saving the resulting data and returning it when requested.

# Overview

In this document, the core requests of the Scenario API are presented in a way similar to the workflow of a scenario analysis execution. Roughly, the following steps are followed:

1.  create a simulation;
2.  execute the created simulation;
3.  access the data generated through scenario analysis.
    

Some other important requests are also presented, but request types such as `PUT` and `PATCH` have not been included, as they're not important for the scenario analysis workflow.

Tests were written for all documented requests. All the requests will have a test that'll check if the status code is correct, while some will have more sophisticated tests for checking the response content and data types.

One thing to keep is mind is that some requests have redundant tests. For example, in "Simulation Detail", there's a test called `Simulation is an object that has only these properties` and another called `Simulation has the correct properties and data types`. The former will fail if the response has any properties other than the ones listed, while the latter will only fail if one of the listed properties is missing (but not if there are extra properties in the response). As such, the former is used as an alert to indicate that the API has been changed and the tests need to be updated, while the latter is used to check for the content of the response itself, since it provides better description of why the test failed.

# Authentication

The current method of Authentication is `BasicAuthentication`, and it's required throughout all API endpoints.

# Error Codes

The user will receive a `200 OK` status code when the following conditions are met:

1.  the request is authenticated;
2.  the accessed endpoint is allowed for the authenticated user;
3.  the authenticated user is the owner of the data he's trying to access (such as a simulation).
    

`201 Created` is returned when a simulation is successfully created through a POST request.

Other possible codes are:

*   `401 Unauthorized` is returned if condition (1.) is not met;
*   `403 Forbidden` is returned if condition (2.) is not met;
*   `404 Not Found` is returned if condition (3.) is not met;
*   `500 Internal Server Error` might be returned if the simulation is executed with bad `scenario_analysis_input`, or if an unknown error happens during scenario analysis.
    

# Rate limit

No rate limit has been established, and no load testing has been done.

formdata.value: Simulation created by sending a request from Postman!

formdata.description: The input for the Simulation's modeller.

request.description:
By sending a `POST` request to the `/simulations` endpoint, the user is capable of creating a new simulation instance. The `scenario_analysis_input` property sent with the `POST` request will be saved in the simulation's modeller input, while other input and output data properties will have `null` values until the simulation is successfully executed.

The response is an object containing the created simulation.

request.description:
The `/simulations/{id}/execute` endpoint will execute Scenario Analysis for the simulation. The input will be collected from the simulation's modeller input, and after a successful execution, the generated files' data will be saved inside the other input and output properties.

The response includes an object with the following properties:
- `errors`: an array of serialization errors that occurred when executing the simulation;
- `postprocessor_output`: the simulation's resulting  postprocessor output object.

This request might take some minutes to finish, depending on the contents of the modeller input. The `default_scenario_analysis_input` environment variable used for testing and development has an execution time of approximately 15 seconds.

item.description: This folder contains requests that integrate the API with the Scenario Analysis simulation.

request.description:
The `/postprocessor-input/{id}` endpoint contains the data for the simulation's postprocessor input.

The response contains the following properties:
- `simulation`: the id of the related simulation;
- `url`: the url of the postprocessor input;
- `rep_data`: an object in which the keys are the names of the generated files, and the content inside these keys is the `string` data of the `.rep` files.
- `error_reports`: an object in which the keys are the names of the generated files, and the content inside these keys is the `string` data of the `.txt` files.

If an error occurs in the Scenario Analysis simulation, the `.cfg` files might be empty, and the `.txt` files will have a traceback of the error. Otherwise, the `.txt` files will be empty.

request.description:
The `/groups` endpoint returns a list of the created groups.

The response contains the following properties:

*   pagination properties;
*   `results`: an array of Groups.
    

Each Group contains the following properties:

*   `name`: the Group's name;
*   `url`: the url to the Group detailed view.

exec: // Check if all pagination and results keys are present in the response
pm.test("Response is an object that has pagination properties", () => {
// Check data types of the response
pm.expect(jsonData.count).to.be.a("number", message="count has the wrong data type");
pm.expect(jsonData.results).to.be.an("array", message="results has the wrong data type");

// Check if the listed Simulation is an object that has only the specified properties. This test will fail if a new property is added to the listed Simulation, so it alerts that this and the 'correct properties' test needs to be updated.
pm.test("Listed Simulation is an object that has only the specified properties", () => {

// Check if the listed Simulation has the specified properties. This test still passes if a new property is added to the listed Simulation, as such the previous test was created to alert the implementation change and signal that this test needs to be updated. Both tests exists because this one provides better descriptions when failed, but still passes even though a new property was received.
pm.test("Listed Simulation has the correct properties", () => {
pm.expect(jsonData.results[0].id).to.be.a("number", message="id has the wrong data type");
pm.expect(jsonData.results[0].owner).to.be.a("string", message="owner has the wrong data type")
pm.expect(jsonData.results[0].title).to.be.a("string", message="title has the wrong data type");
pm.expect(jsonData.results[0].date_created).to.be.an("string", message="date_created has the wrong data type");
pm.expect(jsonData.results[0].url).to.be.an("string", message="url has the wrong data type");
